results.name: Number of solutions to c(1)*prime(4) + ... + c(n)*prime(n+3) = 2, where c(i) = +-1 for i > 1, c(1) = 1.
comment: Each second entry is 0 because the primes that are involved are all odd and the right hand side is even. - _R. J. Mathar_, Aug 06 2015

mathematica: b[n_, s_, p_] := b[n, s, p] = If[n <= s, If[s == p, Boole[n == s], b[Abs[n - p], s - p, NextPrime[p - 1, -1]] + b[n + p, s - p, NextPrime[p - 1, -1] ]], If[s <= 0, b[Abs[s], Sum[Prime[i], {i, p + 1, p + n - 1}], Prime[p + n - 1]]]] /. Null -> 0; a[n_] := b[n, 2 - Prime[4], 4]; Array[a, 50] (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Feb 14 2018, after _M. F. Hasler_ *)
program: (PARI) A022920(n)={my(p=vector(n-1,i,prime(i+4)));sum(i=1,2^(n-1),sum(j=1,#p,(1-bittest(i,j-1)<<1)*p[j],7)==2)} \\ For illustrative purpose; too slow for n >> 20. - _M. F. Hasler_, Aug 08 2015

(PARI) a(n, s=2-prime(4), p=4)=if(n<=s, if(s==p, n==s, a(abs(n-p), s-p, precprime(p-1))+a(n+p, s-p, precprime(p-1))), if(s<=0, a(abs(s), sum(i=p+1, p+n-1, prime(i)), prime(p+n-1)))) \\ _M. F. Hasler_, Aug 09 2015
